item.title: BGP Protocol and its Security
item.description: Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) is a routing protocol used particularly on the Internet. Its objective is to exchange networks (IP address + mask) with its neighbors through TCP sessions (on port 179).

item.title: Network Flows
item.description:
Introduction link

Network flows about network denial of service attacks is the subject addressed here. Indeed, network flows allow for very simple detection of distributed denial of service attacks due to the quantity of flows generated by the zombie army attacking you.

In this article, we’ll present other applications of these network flows: intrusion detection or policy violation, detection of hidden channels, or even worm proliferation to name just a few examples. While the detection of distributed denial of service is something relatively specific to operators and Internet service providers, are the other applications well suited to an internal network?

item.title: TCP Flags
item.description:
TCP Flags Explained link

If you’re not used to analyzing network packet behavior, it’s easy to forget what certain TCP flag abbreviations mean:

  • FIN - Finish; end of session
  • SYN - Synchronize; indicates request to start session
  • RST - Reset; drop a connection
  • PUSH - Push; packet is sent immediately
  • ACK - Acknowledgement
  • URG - Urgent
  • ECE - Explicit Congestion Notification Echo
  • CWR - Congestion Window Reduced
